results.title: Sweet sixteen
results.creator_credit: Ken Loach, Rebecca O'Brien, Alta Films, Tornasol Films, Road Movies and Sixteen Films
results.brief_description: From the same talented writer (Paul Laverty) and director (Ken Loach) team of “My name is Joe” fame, comes a well-made but similarly realistic and despairing film about the harsh life of a fifteen year-old Scottish youth. Liam (Martin Compston) wants a new life for his mother when she gets out of prison and foils plans by her boyfriend to smuggle drugs inside during a visit with he and his grandfather. After a severe beating by the boyfriend and being kicked out of home by his grandfather, Liam takes refuge at his sister Chantelle’s house (Annmarie Fulton). Liam and his best mate Pinball (William Ruane) try and raise some cash to buy a caravan for his mother on her release but the boys get involved with drug trafficking and gangsters, resulting in a series of events that are also their undoing. Winner of Best Screenplay Award Cannes Film Festival 2002. A UK/German/Spanish co-production.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Loach, Rebecca O’Brien, Alta Films, Tornasol Films, Road Movies and Sixteen Films

results.title: Sweet love, bitter
results.creator_credit: Herbert Danska, Louis W Kellman, Lewis Jacobs and Film Three Productions
results.brief_description: Fictional chronicle depicting the last years of jazz musician’s Charlie ‘Bird’ Parker’s life. Capturing the trials and tribulations of a black musician in white America, this film takes an in-depth look at the multi-faceted world of the jazz life — music, drink, drugs, racism, women, and indifference. Features Dick Gregory in the key role as Richie ‘Eagle’ Stokes, with Don Murray playing a down-and-out professor. Adapted from the John A. Williams’ novel “Night song”.

results.title: All change please
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Against the Grain” in association with Partners in Grain (PING).
“All change please. That’s what they say when the train is at the last station.” Diana Anderson began her journey around 23 years ago when she moved on to her husband’s family farm in north-west Victoria. Worked on for generations, Diana and Choco improved and changed the farming business, raising their two boys and enjoying the life for almost 23 years. That is until they were confronted with the distressing news the family partnership was to be sold. For Diana this was the end of one journey and the start of another - a new beginning.

results.title: Swimming upstream
results.creator_credit: Russell Mulcahy, Andrew Mason, Paul Pompian, Karen Baldwin, Howard Baldwin, LLC and Crusader Entertainment
results.brief_description: Based on the book by Anthony and Diane Fingleton, “Swimming upstream” chronicles the turbulent life of the Fingleton family in 1950s Brisbane. In particular, that of Anthony (Tony) Fingleton (Jesse Spencer), younger brother John (Tim Draxl), and their father Harold (Geoffrey Rush). Tony and John were swimming champions, Tony in backstroke and John in freestyle. The siblings were close, especially during the years in which Tony, bullied by older brother Harold Jnr (mimicking the boorish behaviour of his father) for being effeminate finds solace in John and their mother. The patriarch is an overbearing presence, his emotions vacillating between devotion and belligerence. His mood, affected by alcoholism, takes a violent turn directed towards the rest of the family. Harold takes it upon himself to coach his two sons to swimming success but creates a cleft between them when he forces John to change strokes and race against his brother. Regret, machismo and emotional repression play out in this poignant film of a dysfunctional family that makes effective use of split screens to intensify the numerous races and an evocative instrumental soundtrack. Cast also includes Judy Davis as Harold’s long suffering wife Dora.

results.title: Sweet dreams [the story of Patsy Cline]
results.creator_credit: Karel Reisz, Bernard Schwartz and Silver Screen Partners
results.brief_description: Jessica Lange stars as country-western singer Patsy Cline, whose tragic death in 1963 cut short one of the most fabulous success stories in the annals of popular music. In contrast with Cline’s rise to fame in the years between 1956 and 1963, her private life was turbulent and tragic. As the wife of hard-drinking Charlie Dick (Ed Harris), Patsy is subjected to all manner of abuse and humiliation, yet she stays on. A happy second marriage is all too short-lived, as is Patsy herself. Patsy Cline’s fans may notice that Robert Gretchell’s screenplay takes quite a few liberties with details of Patsy’s life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Karel Reisz, Bernard Schwartz and Silver Screen Partners

results.title: Sustainability
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Against the Grain” in association with Partners in Grain (PING).
Althea Hunt describes her life as a farmer’s wife from leaving her beloved family in Queensland to joining her husband and running their independent cereal farm in the Millewa district of Victoria. She talks of the enormous changes - the hard work and dealing with the often unrelenting climate of drought and cyclones whilst also raising three young children and maintaining the family unit. For Althea however, it has been exciting and rewarding to see how far their farm has come over the 30 year journey since she left Queensland.
